facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 100 of 1957 was heard by the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 100 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 21, 1955 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Miscellaneous Application O. J. No. 120 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 21, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Miscellaneous Application 0. J. No. 120 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 19, 1957 by IMAM J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. Sep- tember 19. The following Judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by IMAM, J.-

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed the appellant's application under Article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the decision of the Allahabad High Court dismissing the appellants application under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant was appointed temporarily to the Subordinate Agricultural Service of Uttar Pradesh Government by the Director of Agriculture from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: From the affidavits filed in the High Court by the Personal Assistant to the Director of Agriculture of the Government of Uttar Pradesh and the appellant, it would appear that the appellant was appointed from time to time in a temporary capacity to the Subordinate Agricultural Service of the Uttar Pradesh Government by the Director of Agriculture.

facts.text: Appellant served in Group II of Subordinate Agricultural Service from November 16, 1936 to March 18, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: He served in that service during the periods detailed below- In Group II of the Subordinate Agricultural Service From November 16, 1936 to March 18, 1937.

facts.text: Appellant served in Group II from April 1, 1937 to June 29, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: From April 1, 1937 to June 29, 1937.

facts.text: Appellant served in Group II from August 9, 1937 to December 31, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: From August 9, 1937 to December 31, 1937.

facts.text: Appellant served in Group II from January 6, 1938 to February 22, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: From January 6, 1938 to February 22, 1943.

facts.text: Appellant served in Group I of Subordinate Agricultural Service from February 23, 1943 to April 24, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: In Group I of the Subordinate Agricultural Service From February 23, 1943 to April 24, 1944.

facts.text: Appellant appointed to officiate in United Provinces Agricultural Service Class II as Divisional Superintendent of Agriculture from April 25, 1944 with approval of Public Service Commission.

anchor.surface_text: While he was still in the Subordinate Agricultural Service he was appointed to officiate in the United Provinces Agricultural Service Class 11 as a Divisional Superintendent of Agricul- ture with effect from April 25, 1944, with the approval of the Public Service Commission of the United Provinces.

facts.text: Appellant served in Class II of United Provinces Agricultural Service in temporary capacity for about ten years.

anchor.surface_text: He served in Class II of the United Provinces Agricultural Service in a temporary capacity for about ten years

facts.text: Appellant reverted to Subordinate Agricultural Service by order of Uttar Pradesh Government dated May 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: when he was reverted to his original appointment in the Subordinate Agricultural Service by an order of the Uttar Pradesh Government dated May 3, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant protested reversion, handed over charge on May 16, 1954, and went on leave until October 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant protested against his reversion and handed over charge on May 16, 1954 and went on leave until October 2, 1954.

facts.text: Notice dated September 13, 1954 issued by Director of Agriculture terminating appellant's services in Subordinate Agricultural Service under Rule 25 clause 4.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, a numberice dated September 13, 1954, terminating the appellants services in the Subordinate Agricultural Service was issued to him by the Director of Agriculture. The numberice purported to be under r. 25 cl.  4  of the Subordinate Agriculture Service Rules.

facts.text: Termination notice stated services not required after one month from date of order.

anchor.surface_text: This numberice stated that the appellants services would number be required after the expiry of one month from the date of the issue of the order terminating his services.

facts.text: Appellant challenged validity of reversion and termination orders.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the validity of the aforesaid orders of reversion and termination of his services.

facts.text: High Court held appellant had not been dismissed or removed from service and Article 311 did not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in dismissing his application came to the companyclu- sion that the appellant had number been dismissed or removed from service and that Art. 311 of the Constitution did number apply in the circumstances of the case.

facts.text: It was conceded on behalf of appellant that he was never confirmed in any post in Subordinate Agricultural Service or United Provinces Agricultural Service Class II.

anchor.surface_text: It was companyceded before us on behalf of the appellant that at numbertime was he companyfirmed in any post either in the Subordi- nate Agricultural Service or in the United Provinces Agri- cultural Service Class 11.

facts.text: Supreme Court found High Court's finding that appellant failed to establish confirmation in Subordinate Agricultural Service was correct.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the finding of the High Court that the appellant had failed to establish that he was companyfirmed as a member of the Subordinate Agri- cultural Service, based upon the materials before it, was a companyrect finding.

facts.text: Supreme Court found High Court's finding that appellant not absorbed in permanent cadre of United Provinces Agricultural Service was correct.

anchor.surface_text: The further finding of the High Court that the appellants companytention that he had been absorbed in the permanent cadre of the United Provinces Agricultural Service had number been substantiated appears to us also to be a company- rect finding upon the materials on the record.

facts.text: Appellant was never appointed permanently to either service and was always temporarily employed.

anchor.surface_text: In companysidering the case of the appellant we must proceed on the basis that at numbertime was the appellant appointed perma- nently either to the United Provinces Agricultural Service or to the Subordinate Agricultural Service. At all times he was temporarily employed.

facts.text: Appellant was employed in temporary capacity in Subordinate Agricultural Service and shown in Gradation List as on probation.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the appellant was employed in a tempo- rary capacity in the Subordinate Agricultural Service and was shown in the Gradation List as on probation.

facts.text: Appellant's conditions of service governed by Subordinate Agriculture Service Rules.

anchor.surface_text: His companydi- tions of service  1  1953 S.C.R. 655.  2  1955 1 S.C.R. 26. were governed by the Subordinate Agriculture Service Rules.

issues.text: whether the orders terminating the appellants services and reverting him to his original appointment in the Subordinate Agricultural Service amount to removal, dismissal or reduction in rank within the meaning of the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The question for companysideration, therefore, is whether the orders terminating the appellants services and reverting him to his original appointment in the Subordinate Agricultural Service amount to removal, dismissal or reduction in rank within the mean

issues.text: whether termination of the services of a person employed by the Government amounts in all cases to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of this Court in Satish Chandra Anand v. -The Union of India  1  and in Shyam Lal v. The State of Uttar Pradesh  2  clearly establish that termination of the serv- ices of a person employed by the Government does number amount in all cases to dismissal or removal from service.

issues.text: whether the termination of the appellants services under r. 25 4 amounts to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311

anchor.surface_text: Rule 25 4 of these Rules permits the Director of Agricul- ture to terminate the services of a person on probation by giving him one months numberice if that person has number made sufficient use of his opportunities or if he has otherwise failed to give satisfaction. The termination of the appellants services under r. 25 4  does number amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the companyditions of service applicable to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this appeal it is unnecessary to decide in what circumstances a reversion would be regarded as reduction in rank as the appellant has number established as a fact that the order of reversion passed against him was by way of a penal- ty. The order of reversion, therefore, did number companytravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was a valid order.

arguments.claim: Appellant failed to establish confirmation in Subordinate Agricultural Service

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the finding of the High Court that the appellant had failed to establish that he was confirmed as a member of the Subordinate Agri- cultural Service, based upon the materials before it, was a correct finding.

anchor.surface_text: The further finding of the High Court that the appellants contention that he had been absorbed in the permanent cadre of the United Provinces Agricultural Service had not been substantiated appears to us also to be a cor- rect finding upon the materials on the record.

holdings.text: the finding of the High Court that the appellant had failed to establish that he was confirmed as a member of the Subordinate Agricultural Service, based upon the materials before it, was a correct finding.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the finding of the High Court that the appellant had failed to establish that he was confirmed as a member of the Subordinate Agri- cultural Service, based upon the materials before it, was a cor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of materials on record supports High Court's evaluation of evidence on confirmation.

holdings.text: the appellants contention that he had been absorbed in the permanent cadre of the United Provinces Agricultural Service had not been substantiated... a correct finding upon the materials on the record.

anchor.surface_text: The further finding of the High Court that the appellants contention that he had been absorbed in the permanent cadre of the United Provinces Agricultural Service had not been substantiated appears to us also to be a cor- rect finding upon the materials on the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's assessment of evidence on absorption upheld as correct.

holdings.text: at no time was the appellant appointed permanently either to the United Provinces Agricultural Service or to the Subordinate Agricultural Service. At all times he was temporarily employed.

anchor.surface_text: In considering the case of the appellant we must proceed on the basis that at no time was the appellant appointed permanently either to the United Provinces Agricultural Service or to the Subordinate Agricultural Service. At all times he was temporarily employed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from accepted facts of appointments and lack of confirmation or absorption.

holdings.text: termination of the services of a person employed by the Government does not amount in all cases to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of this Court in Satish Chandra Anand v. The Union of India 1 and in Shyam Lal v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 2 clearly establish that termination of the serv- ices of a person employed by the Government does not amount in all cases to dismissal or removal from service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following binding precedents in Satish Chandra Anand and Shyam Lal distinguishing simple termination from punitive action.

holdings.text: The termination of the appellants services under r. 25 4 does not amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the conditions of service applicable to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 25 4 of these Rules permits the Director of Agriculture to terminate the services of a person on probation by giving him one months notice if that person has not made sufficient use of his opportunities or if he has otherwise failed to give satisfaction. The termination of the appellants services under r. 25 4  does not amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the conditions of service applicable to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule permits termination by notice for probationer; complies with service conditions, analogous to contractual termination upheld in precedents.

holdings.text: The order complained against did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was therefore a valid order.

anchor.surface_text: In principle, we cannot see any clear distinction between the termination of the services of a person under the terms of a contract governing him and the termination of his services in accordance with the terms of his conditions of service. The order complained against did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was therefore a valid order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination order follows service rules without punitive intent, no violation of Art. 311 protections.

holdings.text: Reversion from a temporary post held by a person does not per se amount to reduction in rank because the temporary post held by him is not his substantive rank.

anchor.surface_text: Reversion from a temporary post held by a person does not per se amount to reduction in rank because the temporary post held by him is not his substantive rank.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reduction in rank assessed against substantive rank, not temporary officiating post.

holdings.text: the appellant has not established as a fact that the order of reversion passed against him was by way of a penalty. The order of reversion, therefore, did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was a valid order.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this appeal it is unnecessary to decide in what circumstances a reversion would be regarded as reduction in rank as the appellant has not established as a fact that the order of reversion passed against him was by way of a penalty. The order of reversion, therefore, did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was a valid order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence reversion punitive; unnecessary to define penalty circumstances as fact not proven.

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of this Court in Satish Chandra Anand v. The Union of India 1 and in Shyam Lal v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 2 clearly establish that termination of the serv- ices of a person employed by the Government does not amount in all cases to dismissal or removal from service.

The order companyplained against did number companytravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was therefore a valid order. Reversion from a temporary post held by a person does number per se amount to reduction in rank because the temporary post held by him is number his substantive rank. anchor.surface_text: Rule 25 4 of these Rules permits the Director of Agriculture to terminate the services of a person on probation by giving him one months notice if that person has not made sufficient use of his opportunities or if he has otherwise failed to give satisfaction. The termination of the appellants services under r. 25 4  does not amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the conditions of service applicable to the appellant.
